 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT AZERBAIJAN REPUBLIC FARM PRIVATIZATION PROJECT I. AGRICULTURE SECTOR IN AZERBAIJAN: PROBLEMS AND OPPORTUNITIES A. INTRODUCTION 1.1 Reform and restructuring of the agricultural sector in Azerbaijan is vital to improve the living standards of the rural people, who comprise 46 percent of the growing population. The agriculture sector employs an estimated 36 percent of the labor force, and contributes between 26 and 30 percent of its GDP. It generates about 30 percent of total exports mostly from cotton, fruits and vegetables. Increasing agricultural productivity in the immediate term is important and will continue to be in the future, even if the foreign exchange earnings from petroleum exports were to recover. After independence in 1991, agricultural production declined (by 13 percent in 1994 following declines of 12 and 25 percent in the preceding two years) and yields have dropped by 30 percent or more for grain, cotton, grapes and tobacco. The overall contribution of agriculture to exports has also declined from about 30 percent to about 10 percent since 1991. Traditionally, agricultural production mostly occurred on collective and state farms, which is gradually being replaced by individual private farms. Agriculture encompasses nine distinct agro-climatic zones giving rise to a highly diversified crop mix. It is dependent on irrigation and imports of the key inputs, viz. hybrid seeds, fertilizer, pesticides, farm machinery and equipment. About half of the total agricultural land (4.4 million ha) is used for crop production with the remainder being used for natural pastures. About 75 percent of the land (1.5 million ha) used for crop production is dependent on irrigation. B. PROBLEMS AND OPPORTUNITIES IN THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR 1.2 The main problems and the opportunities in the agricultural sector are: (i) Weak Institutional Support: The traditional role of the Government to guide and provide all the necessary means for agricultural production, distribution and marketing for agricultural inputs and outputs has been on the decline during the last four years. However, the absence of alternative support systems has led to rent seeking and control by the few remaining Government monopolies. There is a need to redefine the role of the public and private sectors in the agricultural sector - strengthening those Government institutions which must continue to play a role in a market economy to provide research, extension, public infrastructure and developing private structures to perform direct production, marketing and trade; (ii) Incomplete Liberalization of the Sector: Complete liberalization in output prices of perishable products, viz., fruits, vegetables and livestock products has taken place, which has led to their production almost exclusively in the private sector. However, the agro-processing industries still continue to be predominantly in the public sector, thereby limiting the realization of the full production potential and income increasing opportunities in these products. The Government has partially liberalized the wheat and cotton sectors. With respect to wheat, although the Government is committed to buy 30
 -2 - percent of production at domestic market prices, it is unable to do so due to the hard budget constraints and the producer's requirement for delivery on a cash basis only. In response to these policy changes, the domestic prices of wheat has been rising and they are currently about 55 percent of the average projected import parity price of about US$175/mt (1997-2001). With respect to cotton, while state orders have been eliminated, the Government owned ginneries offer the only alternative, at the present time, for the producers to sell their cotton. While the privatization of the cotton ginneries is being contemplated, the government has consistently raised the procurement price closer to export parity price equivalent. The current farm gate price for cotton has moved significantly towards export parity prices (from US$205/mt during 1994 to US$290/mt during 1995 compared to the average projected export parity price of US$335/mt (1997-2001). These price increases are having the desired effect on farm profitability, which has shown an improvement in the last year; and (iii) Slow Implementation of Land Reforms: The Government's overall land policy aims at providing security of land tenure to individuals in the near term and creation of land markets in course of time. The Constitution of the Azerbaijan Republic provides for private land ownership (Article 29) and was adopted by a National Referendum on 12 November 1995. In this regard, after much debate and time, the Parliament has passed the Land Reform Law (July 16, 1996), which would legalize private land ownership and establish the land distribution procedures. WORLD BANK INITIATIVES 1.3 The Bank's agricultural sector review (July 1995) concluded that Azerbaijan has considerable production potential in many agricultural commodities, especially in cotton, grain, vegetables, fruits and silk production, given the availability of water resources, developed irrigated areas, and stable agro- ecological systems. It has identified the following areas for action: (a) land privatization and farm restructuring of state and collective farms; (b) implementation of market oriented price and trade policies; (c) demonopolization and privatization of state agribusiness enterprises; (d) development of an appropriate rural financial system to serve private farming and agro-enterprises; (e) improve efficiency of water delivery and use for agriculture; and (f) realignment of the role of the Government in the agricultural sector. 1.4 The CAS for FY97-99 was developed in collaboration with the Government and focuses on agriculture, poverty alleviation and post war reconstruction. The Bank's program would emphasize four main areas: (i) enhancement of competitiveness in critical economic sectors: for the CAS period, the sector focus will be on agriculture with emphasis on: (a) creation of land markets and accelerating the privatization of state and collective farms within an appropriate transparent legal framework; (b) demonopolization of state owned enterprises involved in input and output marketing channels and commodity exchange; (c) designing a rural credit scheme to serve the emerging private farmers; and (d) rehabilitation of dilapidated irrigation and drainage systems and rural infrastructure; (ii) establishment of a policy and institutional framework conducive to efficient and equitable private sector led sustainable growth. This would be implemented through mainly institution building components in agriculture, finance and industrial sectors; (iii) alleviating poverty through the development of improved targeting of social assistance, increasing efficiency of health care services, and designing a national poverty alleviation strategy; and (iv) resettlement and rehabilitation of IDPs and refugees through building institutional capacity in the Government to support and implement the reconstruction effort and undertaking reconstruction of occupied territories. These program initiatives translate into a base case lending program of four IDA and one IBRD operations totalling US$170 million over FY97-99. If the country performance improves, the lending program would expand to comprise up to five IDA and two IBRD operations totalling US$295 million over the FY97-99 CAS period, which is about US$12 per capita per annum - an average for similarly performing economies. 1.5 The farm privatization project is fully consistent with the CAS and has been developed in close consultation with the Government. The project directly supports the Government's program to transform the agricultural sector into one based on market principles. The Government's recent initiatives to create an appropriate policy environment for land privatization and farm restructuring provides the basis for the proposed project. Successful and speedy implementation of the proposed project would induce more efficient use of scarce resources and enable the new farm structures to base their production decisions on market forces rather than to the dictates of the state.

PRESENT STATUS OF FARM RESTRUCTURING 2.3 Until 1991, the farming structure in Azerbaijan consisted of 983 collective farms and 820 state farms, cultivating a total of 1.46 million hectares. The Government intends to privatize 70 percent of the farms and agribusinesses as soon as possible. However, the progress in creating the necessary conditions and implementation has been slow due to lack of resources and the know-how. The decision making process for farm restructuring involves the following steps: the raion Administration notifies the eligible farms to submit their proposals for privatization of the farm for consideration and approval. The decision to re-organize is taken by the local farm Commission'!. The concerned farm in the General Body meeting discusses the reorganization plans and takes decisions concerning the division of farm land into independent parcels and the form of organization, such as joint stock companies, association of peasant farms, collectives, cooperatives, or independent units. 2.4 Local initiatives by voluntarily created groups are being taken for the division and distribution of agricultural lands of state and collective farms at the village level. For example, in the Salyan raion, 24 out of 27 farms have completed the following steps: (i) carried out a complete inventory and valuation of movable and immovable properties of the farm including land assets; (ii) defined the eligibility criteria for sharing of movable farm property among the members of the farm and the criteria for distribution of land among the inhabitants of the village after reserving certain portions of the land for future contingencies; and (iii) have decided and allocated the land to individual, family or groups of farmers on the basis of lottery. The raion administration has issued temporary land ownership certificates to each of the group leaders, family head or individual land parcel holder. The certificates indicate the area, coordinates, boundary, land quality and locational details. The raion administration would replace the temporary land certificate with a legally valid land certificate. These records will be maintained officially by the State Land Committee. A similar situation exists in all the farms proposed for pilot development under the project (para. 2.8). 2.5 While improvements are noticeable both in the quantities and qualities of vegetables, fruits and livestock products, farms are unable to exploit the full potential of the available resources. This is because a majority of the farm members have not yet been able, to claim individual ownership; to voluntarily determine how to use their newly acquired land and non-land assets; and to reconstitute themselves as individual farms, joint stock companies, holding companies, partnerships and lease holders or other suitable forms. The guiding principles which would govern the process of farm restructuring has been described in Box 2.2. STATUS OF PRIVATIZATION IN THE FIvE PROJECT FARMs 2.7 Significant progress was made in the second half of 1995 in initiating privatization on the project farms. In all five locations, procedures are being followed as laid-down by the Government regulation on privatization. There are, however, differences between farms in the precise arrangements and pace of transition. Each of the five rayons has established a privatization commission with membership including rayon-level specialists and farmers' representatives nominated by the intended farmers. A technical committee on each farm was elected, in association with each commission, specifically to undertake inventories and valuations of fixed and movable assets and to make recommendations to the commission on mechanisms for dividing them between qualifying residents on the kolkhozes and sovkhozes. In addition to this, at Barda, a "disputes" committee has been established, with membership consisting of agricultural researchers, experienced farmers and legal specialists, to advise individuals or groups of intended farmers on organizational, technical and legal questions. 2.8 Decisions have been made, discussed and accepted by the intended farmers on the distribution of assets on all five project farms. For three farms in Barda, Udjar and Lenkoran, a land share has been allocated to all persons of 18 years or over currently living on the kolkhozes. In Salyan, the qualifying age is fourteen years and on Xachmaz all residents are shareholders, irrespective of age. The individual land share-holdings vary: Barda 1.3 ha, Udjar 1.6 - 2.0 ha, Salyan 1.2 ha, Lenkoran 0.1 ha and Xachmaz 0.3 ha. In all cases, farm workers, pensioners, social workers (schools and health), disabled people and off-farm workers (e.g., military) qualify as land shareholders. 2.9 Shareholders on all farms are free to exit with land rights and there is no control over prospective buyers. Land and property within the villages is already being traded. The newly emerging farmers on all five farms do not anticipate sale of farmland in the foreseeable future, because of its security value. However, where necessary, there is provision for payments to be made in accordance with shares values established by the Privatization Commission. Shares in the few farm buildings on two project farms (Barda and Udjar) are being distributed amongst the personnel currently working in them. On the remaining farms, shares are divided between all members. In all cases it has been agreed that charges will be levied on individual farmers that use of the buildings, e.g., farm produce stores. Machinery shares in four of the project farms have been allocated to all shareholders; the exception is Barda where the local commission agreed to provide the share to the workers directly involved. Livestock shares also have been allocated either to the workers directly involved as in Barda or to all shareholders in the other four project farms, where shares in livestock have been allocated to all members, shareholders will generally receive annual dividends; in the case of Lenkoran the dividend is part of a monthly salary. 2.10 Organization of the newly privatized farms will inevitably change considerably in the coming years. However, for the immediate future, a majority of new farmers have opted to create groups (similar to working brigades in the previous system) and to cultivate their land in blocks. These are organized on a village basis and their location is decided in accordance with proximity to the village concerned. Precise land allocation within each block will be decided by lottery. Provisional certificates to each shareholder are being issued. Group of farmers on most of the project farms took charge of the land in late 1995 and, therefore, these kolkhozes/sovkhozes are, in effect already disbanded.

Shareholders on three of the five farms have agreed to maintain the existing machinery pools on all project farms as a single operation and the groups mostly intend to contract with the privatized machinery pool (agro-service) for basic cultivation work. The active labor force in each group is excessive for the most economical operation of the blocks of land concerned and the new farmers have clearly accepted that profitable operation depends on maximizing manual labor, e.g., for weeding and cotton picking. In the same way, the new farmers are enthusiastic to participate in reconstruction work of the irrigation schemes. They also accept their responsibilities for maintaining irrigation and drainage channels on their blocks of land and the payment of water charges. Similarly, new farmers accept the need for and implications of obtaining credit for initiating production on their farm blocks. Prospects 2.12 The present production systems are physically and economically suited to the farms and with rehabilitation, extension, and modernization of irrigation and drainage facilities, offer good potential as profitable intensive farming enterprises. With improved macroeconomic conditions and the liberalized price and trade regimes, the emerging farms would be able to operate as independent units, if they are provided with working capital for seasonal inputs and investment in more efficient technologies. As international experience has demonstrated, individual farms and enterprises have proven to be far more efficient and productive than state and collective farms, especially in vegetable and livestock production. This is evident from the factor productivity differentials in private plots and collective farms in project areas. E. KEY PROBLEMS FACED BY PROJECT FARMS 2.13 Other key problems confronting the farms are: (i) Deteriorated On-Farm and Inter-Farm Infrastructure. The irrigation systems in these farms were built during 1966 and 1970s and due to lack of maintenance in recent years have deteriorated. These were designed to serve large scale farms with cropping and management for arable lands ranging in size from 700 to 4500 hectares. Off-farm irrigation water conveyance efficiency is low (less than 50 percent) as the system has deteriorated from lack of maintenance. The poor status of irrigation and drainage canals is the major constraint to farm productivity and, without reconstruction, will further erode farm profitability. Farm buildings and farm access roads also suffer from poor maintenance; (ii) Obsolete Farm Machinery. The neglected state of most machines and equipment poses a serious constraint for timely farm operations. Most of the farm machinery is outdated, obsolete and in need of repairs and replacements; (iii) Lack of Credit and Input Availability. Most of the farms are facing liquidity constraints and are not able to buy inputs. Most inputs such as nitrogenous and potash fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides, seeds, farm machinery are imported; and (iv) Deterioration of Social Services and Quality of Life. Most of the farm population in the five project farms could be classified as vulnerable, resulting from their inability to sell their produce, unpaid salaries, and withdrawal of Government support. Most of the able
 bodied working men have migrated to neighboring countries in search of better employment opportunities. The farms are no longer able to provide social services such as health facilities, child care, schooling, drinking water and sanitation facilities, etc, which once belonged to the former state and collective farm operations. The removal of explicit and implicit food subsidies and the elimination of bread subsidies in 1995 has placed increased hardship, especially on non-working pensioners, women and children. F. LESSONS FROM EXPERENCE FROM OTHER TRANSmON ECONOMIES 2.13 Experience in countries which are undergoing transition from a centrally planned to a market economy has proved that land privatization and farm restructuring is best undertaken in a phased manner consistent with the development of markets, functioning financial intermediaries and overall macro- economic stabilization to yield desired results. The process is accelerated as the distortions in the economy are eliminated, procedures refined, legal systems developed and supporting institutions evolve to provide timely support services. Fundamental to this program is to give titles to farm land and property in the hands of farm members - with an opportunity to voluntarily decide how to use these newly acquired rights. Assistance programs should address the severe constraints faced by the privatized farms, in particular: (i) the lack of appropriate information on re-organization laws and procedures; and (ii) inadequate institutional capability to effect the transfer, limited technology choices, need for focused social services, lack of working capital and investment funds for restructuring production systems appropriate for private small-scale farming, and the poor state of irrigation and road infrastructure. The proposed farm privatization project takes into consideration these factors and the components have been designed to address the critical constraints identified from the lessons of experience.

PROJECT OBJECTIVES 3.1 The main objective of the Farm Privatization Project (FPP) is to accelerate the Government's program for land privatization and farm restructuring of representative state and collective farms in a systematic manner and to provide models which could serve as a basis for wider geographical replicability. This objective would be achieved through the provision of: (i) essential support services which are necessary to sustain privatized agriculture at the raion and farm levels. These are: land registration, farm information and advisory services, credit services, and rehabilitation of critical irrigation and drainage infrastructure; (ii) an enabling environment which would help build linkages between key institutions, viz., Ministry of Agriculture, State Land Committee, State Irrigation Committee, Agrarian Reform Commissions and agricultural banking institutions; and (iii) community based social services and formation of village groups in support of land privatization and farm restructuring. 3.2 The project activities are regional and farm specific in nature, and which have been designed to be replicable. At the raion level, the project would support the land registration system, advisory services, credit delivery mechanisms, and re-orientation of the department of agriculture functions to service privatized farms. These support services would have the capability to service the needs of the privatized farms throughout the participating raions and would form the basis for the subsequent development of national systems. At the farm level, the project would develop a business oriented outlook in the privatized farms by providing advisory and credit support to those activities which are financially and economically viable; rehabilitate the main water supply works and field level irrigation and drainage works, and initiate new concepts of field level water management through the formation of water user's associations and implementation of cost recovery mechanisms. The project area consists of representative state and collective farms chosen from the raions of Barda, Lenkoran, Salyan, Udjar, Xachmaz and Sharur in Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic. B. MARKETING ASPECTS 5.8 The market for agricultural produce is firmly set on adjusting to the market economy. Sales of most farm products, including vegetables, fruit and livestock products are totally dictated by the free market. In theory, state orders have continued to apply in 1995 to old kolkhozes and sovkhozes for production of strategic commodities wheat (30 percent of output) and cotton. These state orders have now been abolished. 5.9 Wheat marketing occurs at two levels: (i) any products contracted to the Government are paid for at the point of delivery (local silo); and (ii) output beyond any contracted commitment is partially conserved on the farm as seeds stock and the remainder is distributed to the farm workers as wages. Any part of the workers' share not retained for family consumption is sold in local markets. It is expected that all grain products in 1996 will be sold on the open market. With respect to cotton, it has been sold mostly through the Liverpool commodities exchange and historically, the export crop has been sold to a small number of European importers. Export sales are generally made f.o.b. at the Iran border on the Caspian Sea and cotton is carried by lorry from the ginneries to the Persian Gulf for shipment. Therefore, cotton exports are not affected by international blockades. Since 1993, Government has been unable to totally refinance the cotton crop before export. Therefore, a payment of 30 percent of the lint value is paid on delivery and the remainder from the export receipts - typically in April of the succeeding year. This delay in payment is proving a major disincentive for producers and cotton production has declined drastically, from 400,000 tons in 1991 to 273,000 tons in 1995. During negotiations, it was agreed that the Government would adopt a plan, not later than March 31, 1997, for providing prompt payments to farmers for the procurement of cotton. D. These relate to: (i) sustainability of privatized farms as financially viable units; (ii) replicability of this project; (iii) Government's ability to co-ordinate the multi- disciplinary activities needed for privatization and farm restructuring; and (iv) lack of implementation experience. (i) Project Replicability. The first risk relates to the extent to which the incentives, procedures, policies, investments and selection criteria used in this project could be replicated to other parts of the country, for, herein, lies the success of the project. Although the project farms have been chosen to be representative and have agreed to the principles of farm restructuring, there is a risk that some may not co-operate. In this event, the project would provide for other farms in the raion to participate who are willing to go through the agreed processes and procedures. In addition, the project's emphasis on periodic public dissemination of the privatization and restructuring process throughout the raion and in other parts of the country is expected to jump start other privatization initiatives; (ii) Sustaining Financial Viability of Privatized Farms. The second risk is the continued ability of the privatized farm units to operate as financially viable operations and be able to service the working capital and investment loans. In this regard, the financial analysis, based on conservative yield increases and current market prices, reveals that the "new privatized farms" would be able to generate sufficient cash flows to repay loans. The size of farm holdings would range between 5 to 10 ha per family household, which together with their household "garden plots" and cattle would provide adequate income to continue farming. However, if the price liberalization policies were to be reversed, and the prices remain unchanged, then the rate of return becomes marginal, yielding about 12 percent. The implementation of the Government's price and trade liberalization policies, expected macro-economic stabilization in the near term, resolution of border conflicts and opening of marketing channels is expected to sustain the financial viability of the privatized farms. In this regard, a proposed Structural Adjustment Credit, which would address the broader policy reform areas of liberalization of input and output prices, dismantling of state monopolies and removal of trade restrictions on agricultural inputs and outputs is expected to further minimize this risk; (iii) Coordination and Sequencing of Pre-and Post-Privatization Activities. The third risk is the ability of the Government to co-ordinate the various tasks, sequencing and timely delivery of the services required for farm privatization and restructuring to take place. A clear assignment of agency responsibilities and supervision by the State Commission for Farm Privatization is expected to mitigate the co-ordination problem; and (iv) Lack of Implementation Experience. The fourth risk relates to potential delays in project implementation due to lack of experience of the implementing agencies in IDA/IFAD procedures; obtaining Government agreement to the various criteria, funding mechanisms and co-financing arrangements. The project has taken steps to commence project start up activities through training of key officials in various project related areas, provision of technical assistance; obtaining the most important agreements and commitments from the Government before negotiations and involving IFAD at an early stage of project processing to avoid delays in finalizing co-financing arrangements.

This report is prepared as a part of the environmental program of the Farm Privatization Project in preparation to meet the environmental assessment requirements of Azerbaijan Government and the World Bank. The Bank rules require that an Environmental Analysis (EA) is done prior to the implementation of the Farm Privatization Project. The main crops analyzed were winter wheat, barley, cotton, corn for grain, forage crop, fruits (apples), eggplant and onions. The analysis was carried out under two cases; first using the current input-output technical coefficients and productivity levels - representing the "Without Project Situation" and second; under improved technological practices with improved input-output relationships and higher productivity levels - representing the "With Project Situation". The current market prices for all inputs and outputs were used to evaluate financial viability in both the cases. (i) Without Project Situation: The first case reflects the present status of crop profitability. It shows that the gross margins of the cereal crops, even though positive, are not significant enough to justify new investments unless their operations are restructured and productivity increases are obtained. The gross margins per hectare for wheat, barley, corn for grain and forage crops are in a range between US$47 to US$146 per hectare. Cotton returns are about US$263 per hectare. Vegetables provide the maximum margins of over US$3500 per hectare. The low margins of cereal crops are due to low input use, obsolete technological practices and distortions in relative input-output prices. Productivity, in terms of yields per hectare is low, especially given the high potential of increasing the yields by 50 to 100 percent for most of the crops. In the case of dairy operations, the gross margins are US$153 per cow. This low return is due to poor quality feed - which is low in protein, lack of vitamins, poor livestock management and low hygienic standards; (ii) With Project Situation: The second case analyzes the returns under improved conditions, with better and timely use of inputs, more efficient use of water resources (implied through water charges and formation of water users association), lower harvesting and transport losses and better quality products. The primary objective of the Community Development component is to support suitable mechanisms for people based community development activities and strengthen local groups to take an active part in the land privatization and farm restructuring process. Specifically, this component will support activities that will: (i) ensure that the privatization process is used as an opportunity to increase involvement of the population and that the land distribution process takes place equitably; (ii) assist the people of the villages and target group members to establish confidence in their ability to manage their own affairs at the community level; (iii) provide support to critical community infrastructure through rehabilitation; in particular domestic water supplies and small social infrastructure which could be sustained by the community; and (iv) lay the basis for the sustainable development of off-farm small scale enterprises in the project area. C. STRATEGY 7. The strategy of this component is to actively involve the ordinary village population and provide them with sufficient knowledge and training in order to: (a) develop their ability and confidence in participatory community activities through encouraging members' participation in planning and implementing community initiatives; (b) take an active role in the process of privatization and ensure that their interests as individuals and groups are given due consideration through assuring a demand-driven approach in the identification, assessment and selection of community initiatives; (c) initiate and manage
 - 81- ANNEX G community level activities and investments through improving their capacity to implement and monitor community initiatives; and (d) diversify income sources and increase employment alternatives through the development of off-farm small-scale enterprises. 8. The component would assist in the development of a community based approach to problems which can be dealt with and sustained at the village level and which will not require further involvement of national institutions. Priority would be given to meeting women's needs. Applications from women for training in technical, business and marketing skills as well as for credit would be given first priority, and carefully monitored. D. COMPONENT DESCRIPTION 9. This component consists of four major activities: (i) mass information campaign on the privatization process; (ii) development of local capacities in participatory community development; (iii) rehabilitation of critical community infrastructure; and (iv) creation of new types of employment opportunities in the project area. (i) Information Campaign: This component would initiate and operate a mass information campaign in each village of the project raions. This information campaign would involve: (a) an information campaign to the beneficiaries on the status of the privatization as well as the procedures and options available; and (b) organization of public meetings for the discussion of privatization procedures in each village. (ii) Development of Local Capacities in Participatory Community Development: Once the privatization is underway and the community members have been informed, activities that would speed up the involvement of people in the privatization process and development of local capacities in community development would be undertaken. These would consist of: (a) introduction of participatory planning processes to enable communities to state their needs and priorities, and to enable Community Development Workers and other project staff to translate these needs and priority into coherent community plans; (b) identification and selection of the community level organizers who would be responsible for coordinating community activities; (c) providing community level organizers and community members with the training required to be able to effectively facilitate such processes; and (d) strengthening the ability of communities to select, implement and manage community initiatives. (iii) Rehabilitation of Critical Community Infrastructure: The project would support the rehabilitation of critical community infrastructure in the project farms. Reliable domestic water supply has been found to be a pressing need in most of the project farms, especially in Gulaband and Hatai farms2 in Udjar raion.. 2 Supply pipelines exist but need rehabilitation of about 1 km. The distribution point for three villages is located next to the offices of Hatai farm, which is also in need of repair and replacement of some equipment. Some new parts of the village are not connected by the pipeline system, which need to be extended by about 1 km. Additional pumps would need to be installed. There are currently no house connections. The system is also turned off due to considerable debts by the farms which were responsible for paying the bills until recently. Similar interventions could be planned later for other communities. In Gilinjili where water is supplied from four unequipped artisan wells (3 free flowing and one with pump-set), an entirely autonomous community level user's organization for water management could be developed and the wells equipped with basic facilities,

The formation of such user groups would be initiated in Gilinjili and if successful, would be replicated to other villages in the five project farms where development of village level water supply systems are technically feasible and financially within the possibilities of the project. Loans will be made by Agroprombank and only a one-time capital grant up to 50 percent of the total capital required for commercially viable activities and the remaining balance of 50 percent would be provided as a term credit to the beneficiaries. The Joint-Stock Agricultural Industrial Bank of the Azerbaijan Republic, registered in accordance with the law "About Banks and Banking activities" in the National Bank of the Azerbaijan Republic with the following address: 125 Kadirli Street Baku 370099 Azerbaijan Republic Telex: 142384 " Dinar S. Vurgun Street Baku 370601 Azerbaijan Republic acting on behalf and for the Government of the Azerbaijan Republic. Main Objective Of The Agreement 3. The Ministry of Finance hereby intends to enter into a subsidiary financing agency agreement with the Agroprombank (APB) to utilize a portion of the IDA credit and IFAD loan made to the Government of Azerbaijan Republic for the purposes of providing credit to: Privatized farm units emerging from the privatization process of Ghilinjili farm in Barda raion; Narimanov farm in Lenkoran Raion; Shafag farm in Salyan Raion; Gulaband-Hatai farms in Udjar Raion; Yergouz farm in Xachmaz Raion; and Sharur farm of Sharur raion of Nakhchivan autonomous republic of the Azerbaijan Republic. Agroprombank As An Agent Bank 4. APB will function as an agent bank for the Ministry of Finance to channel a portion of the funds received as credit from the International Development Association of the World Bank Group and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. It means that the Agroprombank will not take the financial and credit risks, as its present financial situation does not permit it to borrow from IDA/IFAD/MOF. These risks will be taken by the Government of Azerbaijan Republic. The major
 - 104 - ANNEX I functions of APB acting as an agent bank will be: (i) on-lending, supervision and recovery to the prospective private farmers/farming units that will emerge from the privatization process and meet the eligibility criteria as explained in para 10; (ii) maintain proper custody of loan funds; (iii) repayment to Ministry of Finance of the interest from the loans and reinvestment of principal repayments for the first ten years; and (iv) the project loan funds should be separated from its own resources. Purpose Of Funds Provided To Agroprombank 5. These are: (i) To utilize funds for stated purposes and activities required to fulfill agreed project objectives. These are expected to be for: (a) working capital loans for seasonal farm inputs such as seeds, fertilizer, pesticides, labor, fuel machinery services and transport; (b) purchase of farm equipment and spares; (c) on-farm capital expenditures for land and building improvements; (d) field level irrigation and drainage works; (iv) small businesses and agro-industries processing the farm produce; and (f) community development activities; and (ii) To appraise loans and projects as per IDA's and IFAD's guidelines and ensure that viable activities meeting financial, economic, technical and environmental criteria are financed. Terms And Conditions For APB To Function As An Agent Bank 6. The terms and conditions for APB to function as an agent bank are: (i) APB will receive commissions and fees for managing the credit line based on its performance in disbursing the line of credit and sub-loan recovery from private farmers. The fee structure will be as follows: (a) APB will charge a two percent appraisal fee up-front and receive an additional annual commission of up to two percent to be collected from interest paid by borrowers in cash on an arrears basis which will be approved by the State Commission for Farm Privatization; (b) During the initial ten year period, the reflows to the APB from all sub-loan principal repayments will be recycled and relent for the same purposes; and the interest payments will be made to the Ministry of Finance during this period to service IDA credit and IFAD loan; and (c) After the first ten years, the Ministry of Finance will review the situation and formulate new arrangements as appropriate in consultation with IDA and IFAD. (ii) Funds would be provided to APB from the special account set up for the project and would follow IDA/IFAD withdrawal procedures as set out in the Development Credit Agreement of IDA and IFAD Loan agreement.
 - 105 - ANNEX I On-lending Terms, Conditions And Loan Ceilings From Agroprombank To Borrowers 7. These are: (i) Sub-loans to borrowers will be provided in manats at the twelve month manat rate set by the National Bank; (ii) The sub-borrowers will repay in manats; (iii) APB in consultation with MOF will review such rates with IDA/IFAD from time to time; not charge extra commissions, compensating balances, fees, etc. to increase effective costs to borrowers beyond agreed rates and fees; (iv) Each sub-loan will be issued for a maximum period of ten years including a maximum grace period of three years; (v) The maximum amount of sub-loans per borrower shall be (i) for working capital up to US$500 per hectare; (ii) for farm machinery, equipment and small scale processing units up to US$30,000; (iii) for land improvements and field level infrastructure works up to US$1500 per hectare; and (iv) for community development activities up to US$1000; and (vi) Each sub-loan will be subject to a right of suspension upon failure by the borrower to perform its obligation under the agreement. Grants For Eligible Borrowers 8. These will be: (i) A one time capital grant of up to 25 percent of the land improvement/on-farm infrastructure works would be provided to eligible borrowers; (ii) A one time capital grant of up to 50 percent of the total investment capital required for commercially viable development may be provided to each beneficiary from the project farms; and (iii) These Grants would be provided from the IDA credit by the Government of Azerbaijan to eligible borrowers and will not be subject to recovery by Agroprombank. The total amount of grants to be made available will be limited to US$100,000 per farm (a total of US$ 600,000 for the project farms). Sub-Loan Approval Procedures 9. The raion level implementation unit, consisting of representatives of the State Land Committee, State Irrigation Committee, Department of Agriculture, Water User's Association, local APB branch and credit advisor would be responsible for approving sub-loans up to a maximum of US$30,000, which have been appraised and found suitable for financing. Sub-loans amounting to US$30,000 and above would need the approval of the State Commission for Farm Privatization.
 - 106 - ANNEX I Security Of Credit And Repayment 10. Sub-loans will be extended on the basis of the following (i) Eligibility criteria of borrower: The following eligibility criteria of the borrower shall apply: (aj Must have a title or certificate to the farmland; (b) Must have gone through the privatization process and operate as a privatized farm unit or enterprise according to the Laws of Azerbaijan; (c) Submit a business plan demonstrating the economic and financial viability of farm operations; and (d) Must be willing to follow IDA/IFAD procurement procedures; and (ii) Credit agreements signed between the Agroprombank and borrowers specifying repayment amounts and dates; (iii) Appropriate security would be taken to protect the creditor's interest: The borrower shall agree to provide: (a) a record of lien on registered land as collateral when the Land law permits a formal mortgage of land; and (b) a lien on assets financed by the sub-loan; (iv) APB will undertake all legal work to register security interest; (v) APB will maintain comprehensive credit files for each sub-loan; and (vi) APB will fully co-operate with external auditors employed to audit the credit line; such auditors to be approved by IDA and IFAD. Accounting Procedures 11. APB offices at Baku and its branches in the five raions of Barda, Lenkoran, Salyan, Udjar and Xachmaz will: (i) Implement accounting and management information systems to provide up to date information on credit utilization and recoveries; (ii) Maintain separate project accounts for the borrowers in each of the project raions and at Baku; and (iii) Provide annual audited accounts by an independent auditor who shall be appointed early in the fiscal year to complete the audit within three months of the completion of the year.
 - 107 - ANNEX I Terms Of Institutional Support 12. APB will be strengthened in agricultural credit and banking procedures; accounting and management information systems. APB will be provided with computers and related accessories, office equipmenL and supplies, training and technical assistance. This institutional support of not more than US$500,000, (Five Hundred Thousand US Dollars) from the IDA credit will be provided by the Ministry of Finance to APB for a period of ten years at an interest rate of 0.75 percent and five years grace for this purpose. Review of the Agency Agreement 13. This agency agreement between the Ministry of Finance and Agroprombank and the situation of the Agroprombank would be reviewed in mid 1998 to explore whether it is appropriate to make suitable modifications at that time, including making the envisaged restructured Agroprombank to take the credit risk. Termination Of This Agreement 14. This agreement shall be suspended, cancelled or terminated if: (i) Agroprombank fails to perform any of its obligations under this agreement; and (ii) funds made available to APB for on- lending to eligible borrowers shall become due and payable to the Ministry of Finance according to the agreed terms and conditions. 15. This agreement is governed by and be construed in accordance with the laws of the Azerbaijan Republic. This agreement is made in four duplicates, each of which is in original. doc.abstracts: The main objective of the Farm Privatization Project (FPP) is to accelerate the Government's program for land privatization and farm restructuring of representative state and collective farms in a systematic manner and to provide models which could serve as a basis for wider geographical replicability. This objective will be achieved by providing: (1) essential support services necessary to sustain privatized agriculture at the raion and farm levels. These are: land registration, farm information and advisory services, credit services, and rehabilitation of critical irrigation and drainage infrastructure; (2) an enabling environment which will build linkages between key institutions, viz., the Ministry of Agriculture, the State Land Committee, the State Irrigation Committee, Agrarian Reform Commissions and agricultural banking institutions; and (3) a community based social services and formation of village groups in support of land privatization and farm restructuring. The project will consist of four components to be implemented over a period of five years. These are: (1) farm privatization support services at the national level and in the raions; (2) rehabilitation of the main irrigation water supply and drainage works; and (3) a community development program; and (4) project management and implementation.
